THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA
NORMAN• OKLAHOMA
Aug. 30, 1952
Dear Graydon:
Ever since Ames, I've been pondering the problems we raised regarding the
position of Executive Director but not getting too far. Let me say that I
think you've done an excellent job in presenting the problem to the Board.
Even the honorable Mr. Paulu couldn’t have done better.
The qualifications which have been set up for the Executive Directorship
are high, so high that I doubt seriously if we can get anyone to fill the
position. Frankly, I don't know of anyone of that caliber who'd be inter¬
ested in the place. George Probst (even though I don’t always agree with
him) might do; Russell Porter was mentioned. I haven't had any contacts
with Porter in several years. I think he'd be a good prospect. Neither of
these measure up to the high qualifications we've set, but they approach.
I'm wondering if Probst would be acceptable to Kellogg?
Suppose we do find someone (Porter & Probst excepted) who is acceptable.
Our present criteria regarding relationship of Executive Director & Board
of Diredtors would need overhauling. To begin with, I'm wondering if a
high-powered man would be interested in routine matters; on the other hand,
would we want him to fool around with membership 3-ists , etc. when he might
be tackling bigger problems and jousting with the windmills of industry
and high finance.
Actually our present rules call more for an Executive Secretary, perform¬
ing, in the main, routine duties which are rather well defined. If we
acquire this Olympian character, we must broaden the duties, powers and
responsibilities of the position. Some people might think this is already
so (Waldo's memo), but actually it is not the case. These changes should
be made before any contact is made so that we can spell out in 1,2,3 fashion
just what the guy must expect. Certainly, we should not be indefinite. In
a way, that's where a lot of our trouble has been.We should be able to make
quite clear What his duties and responsbilitie3 are* We should be explicit
in this matter of final Board approval on all matters involving policy.
Even Scott Fletcher recognizes that this is a MUST in his relationship with
his own board.
If this post is to be more of an Executive Secretary, then I believe Irving
Merrill might be as acceptable as anyone. Irv has grown up considerably,
has an abundance of energy and drive, is young and free for the moment,
knows educational broadcasting and operations and what's more important is
acquainted with the majority of NAEB members.
As ever.
John W. Dunn
